sections.title: Executing Phase Overview
sections.markdown:
The third phase of a PM² project is the Executing Phase. During this phase, the project deliverables are produced and the requestor organisation prepares for their introduction. The Executing Phase begins with a Kick-off Meeting and ends with the acceptance (final or provisional—as per the Deliverables Acceptance Plan) by the requestor side.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-7-1.png)

**Fig 7.1** Executing Phase activities and main outputs

![](/pm2/figures/fig-7-2.png)

**Fig 7.2** Executing Phase artefacts

sections.title: Executing Kick-off Meeting
sections.markdown:
The Executing Phase starts with the Executing Kick-off Meeting. This meeting ensures that the whole Project Team is aware of the project's key elements and rules.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Organises the meeting. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Required participants. |
| Project Manager Assistant (PMA) & Project Support Office (PSO) | Required to attend (if part of the project). |
| Other project roles or stakeholders | Optional participation (as per the project's needs). |

### Inputs
- Business Case and Project Charter
- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- All project plans and logs
- Any requirements documents

### Steps

**Before the Executing Kick-off Meeting:**
1. Plan the meeting.
2. Draft the Meeting Agenda.
3. Send out the Meeting Agenda in advance.
4. Ensure attendance of required participants.
5. Prepare logistics and hand-outs.

**During the Meeting:**
1. Assign a minute-taker.
2. Present the Project Handbook and the Project Work Plan.
3. Present the Communications Management Plan.
4. Agree the conflict-resolution and escalation procedures.
5. Present the Stakeholder Matrix.
6. Present risk, issue and change-management processes.
7. Clarify expectations of the Project Core Team.
8. Agree team ground rules.

**After the Meeting:**
1. Send Minutes of Meeting (MoM) to stakeholders.
2. Ensure issues, risks, decisions and changes are recorded in the logs.

**RAM (RASCI)**

| Role | AGB | PSC | PO | BM | BIG | SP | PM | PCT |
|------|-----|-----|----|----|-----|----|----|-----|
| Executing Kick-off Meeting | I | **A** | C | **S**/C | C | C | **R** | C |

![](/pm2/figures/fig-7-3.png)

**Fig 7.3** Executing Kick-off Meeting inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**
- Minutes of Meeting (MoM) ☑

sections.title: Project Coordination
sections.markdown:
The objective of project coordination is to facilitate the project's progress by continuously providing information to the Project Core Team (PCT) and supporting the completion of assigned work.
Project coordination includes allocating project resources to activities, performing regular quality checks of interim results, maintaining ongoing communication with all project team members, and keeping everyone involved in the project motivated through leadership, negotiations, conflict resolution and appropriate Human Resource management techniques.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Coordinates all project activities. |
| Project Manager Assistant (PMA) | Assists the Project Manager. |
| Business Manager (BM) | May support coordination depending on context. |

### Inputs
- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan

**Note:** Coordination begins at project start and ends at project close, but peaks during Executing.

### Steps
1. Manage and direct project activities and stakeholders.
2. Assign tasks and coordinate their execution.
3. Provide information needed by the PCT.
4. Verify completion of tasks and accept interim deliverables.
5. Provide leadership and maintain motivation.
6. Manage team dynamics.
7. Use negotiation and conflict resolution techniques to maintain effective collaboration.

### RAM (RASCI)

| Role | AGB | PSC | PO | BM | BIG | SP | PM | PCT |
|------|-----|-----|----|----|-----|----|----|-----|
| Project Coordination | I | I | **A** | **S** | I | I | **R** | I |

![](/pm2/figures/fig-7-4.png)

**Fig 7.4** Project Coordination inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**
- Signed-off work assignments

sections.title: Quality Assurance
sections.markdown:
Quality Assurance is the activity of gathering evidence that the project work follows defined quality standards, methodologies and best practices. It seeks to ensure that the project will satisfy the required scope and quality within constraints.
QA activities include verifying project controls, confirming their implementation, and assessing their effectiveness. These are defined in the Quality Management Plan.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Accountable for all QA activities. |
| Project Quality Assurance (PQA) | Establishes QA standards, reviews outputs and deliverables. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Adheres to QA standards. |

### Inputs
- Quality Management Plan
- Project Work Plan

### Guidelines
- QA activities must be part of the Work Plan.
- The PCT must provide evidence of compliance with QA procedures.

### RAM (RASCI)

| Role | AGB | PSC | PO | BM | BIG | SP | PM | PCT |
|------|-----|-----|----|----|-----|----|----|-----|
| Quality Assurance | I | I | I | **S** | C | I | **A** | **R** |

![](/pm2/figures/fig-7-5.png)

**Fig 7.5** Quality Assurance inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**
- Audit Reports
- Updated Project Logs ☑
- Quality Review Report

sections.title: Project Reporting
sections.markdown:
The purpose of Project Reports is to communicate consolidated information concerning project performance to the appropriate stakeholders. Reports include updates on scope, schedule, effort/cost, quality, and the status of risks, issues, changes and outsourcing.
Reports are presented and discussed during project meetings and distributed according to the Communications Management Plan.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Responsible for all Project Reports (except external audit reports). |
| Other project stakeholders | Review the reports. |

### Inputs
- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- Communications Management Plan
- Project Logs
- Project Checklists
- Outputs of Monitor Project Performance

### Guidelines
- Reports support monitoring and control and must be archived during the Closing Phase.
- Tailor report content, format and frequency to stakeholder needs.

### Steps
1. List all reports in the Communications Management Plan.
2. Ensure templates are fit for purpose.
3. Produce reports with the right level of detail.
4. Produce Ad Hoc reports as needed during project crises or special situations.

### RAM (RASCI)

| Role | AGB | PSC | PO | BM | BIG | SP | PM | PCT |
|------|-----|-----|----|----|-----|----|----|-----|
| Project Reporting | I | I | **A** | **S/C** | I/C | I/C | **R** | C |

![](/pm2/figures/fig-7-6.png)

**Fig 7.6** Project Reporting inputs and main roles

### Types of Project Reports

#### Project Status Report
Summarises overall project performance, covering cost, schedule, scope/changes, risks, issues and milestone progress.

#### Project Progress Report
Provides a high-level overview of stakeholders, milestones, deliverables, budget, costs, major issues and achievements.

#### Quality Review Report
Summarises the results of quality assurance activities, non-conformities, recommendations and remediation actions.

#### Contractor Status Report
Submitted by contractors in accordance with the agreed schedule and summarised by the PM in the Project Status Report.

#### Custom or Ad Hoc Reports
Created when specific communication needs arise or for domain-specific reporting (e.g. IT-specific metrics).

### Outputs
- Project Status Report ☑
- Project Progress Report ☑
- Quality Review Report
- Contractor Status Report
- Custom or Ad Hoc Reports

sections.title: Information Distribution & Phase Gate: RfC
sections.markdown:
## Information Distribution

Information distribution refers to the methods used to keep project stakeholders informed through the regular distribution of project reports, as defined in the Communications Management Plan.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Support Office (PSO) | Manages internal communication and assists with document control and baselining. |
| Project Manager (PM) | Ensures the Project Core Team (PCT) has all necessary information. |
| Other project stakeholders | Are kept informed and update the project team about external factors. |

### Inputs
- Communications Management Plan
- Project Work Plan
- Project Reports and Project Logs
- Minutes of Meetings (MoMs)

### Guidelines
- Communicate relevant information at the right time and in the right format.
- Hold meetings frequently enough to meet stakeholder needs.
- Send regular Status and Progress Reports.

### Steps
1. Carry out activities defined in the Communications Management Plan.
2. Inform stakeholders of updates to the Project Work Plan.
3. Communicate changes to key project documents and logs.
4. Send Project Reports as per the Communications Management Plan.

### RAM (RASCI)

| Role | AGB | PSC | PO | BM | BIG | SP | PM | PCT |
|------|-----|-----|----|----|-----|----|----|-----|
| Information Distribution | I | I | **A** | C | I | I | **R** | C |

![](/pm2/figures/fig-7-7.png)

**Fig 7.7** Information Distribution inputs and main roles

---

## Phase Gate: RfC (Ready for Closing)

The third and final phase gate. A review and approval are recommended before the project can move to the Closing Phase.
The Project Manager (PM) verifies that all goals of the Executing Phase have been achieved, all activities completed, requirements met, and deliverables fully produced.
The PM also ensures that the Project Owner (PO) has accepted the deliverables (final or provisional), that transition activities are completed, and that outputs are available to end-users.
Once all conditions are met, the Project Steering Committee (PSC) can authorise the transition to the Closing Phase.
PM² provides a Phase Exit Review Checklist for each phase to support this assessment.
